DIV1.P: The HIGHLAND VISIONS, OR THE SCOTS NEW PROPHECY: Declaring in TWELVE VISIONS what Strange THINGS shall come to Pass in the Year 1712

P.HI: Entred in the Hall Book, according to Act of Parliament

DIV1.P: London: Printed for J. Baker in Paternoster Row. 1712.

DIV1.HEAD: THE PREFACE.
DIV1.P: THis is but the second Time that the Author hereof hath undertaken to appear in this publick Manner, although he has for many Years been known to have strangely fortold several Things, which have precisely come to pass: As in particular; At the Peace of Reswick, he foretold, that in a short time the War would break forth a∣gain: He foretold the great Storm, and several other Things; and having the second Sight, he has said many Strange and Wonderful Things in a Manner so unaccounta∣ble, that none have come near him in this Age.

He was perswaded the last Year to give Leave to a Friend to Publish his Prophetick Observations, who did it with an inexcusable Weakness, turning much of it into Jest and Ridicule, and setting the Imaginary and Thread∣bare Name of Isaac Bickerstaff to it: This made the more serious Part of it suspected by Wiser, People, and made the Whole look more like something Prophane and Ro∣mantick than a Prediction of Wonderful Judgments to befal the World.
The Author therefore justly disliking that Method, recom∣mends his Predictions to you this Year, from his own Hand, in a more grave and solemn Manner.

Before he goes on to the Particulars of a Year, equal for Wender with any that have gone before, he bespeaks his Reader to look back upon his last Year, and observe how much of what he said there, came exactly to pass, book suitable to the Circumstance of Time and Place as well as Persons.

First, He foretold the Death of the late Emperor Joseph: but the partial Publisher having been affraid to make it Publick, for Fear of the Resentment of the Emperor's Ministers, He forbore to mention it, though the very Time, and part of the Circumstances, appear in the Original Manuscript, which the Author has now by him,
Next, He foretold the Death of the Dauphin of France in so many Words, the very Month of his Decease; h Words are these, The Dauphine Dyes, &c.
Thirdly, He exactly Predicted the Death of the M¦reschal de Bouffleurs.

Fourthly, He exactly Predicted the Battle between t Turks and the Muscovites, with such exact Circumstan¦ces, that he told you the Pretences both Sides made to the Victory, together with the wasting away of the King Sweden's Forces, without doing any thing considerable.

Fifthly, He foretold you the breaking out of the Plag in the King of Denmark's Dominions, and especially that it should make great Havock in his Capital City Copenhagen, which has been eminently fullfilled, wit many other Things, for which he referrs to his last Year Prophecy, and hopes as he has set out this in a more seri¦ous Manner, it may meet with your more serious At¦tention.

DIV1.HEAD: First Prophecy.
DIV1.P: THE Councils of Europe having been long busie upon the great Dispute about Peace, begin now to fee not so certain as some People imagined; and therefore with great Diligence apply themselves to make prepara¦tions for War; but this is only that the good posture of Affairs on both sides my contribute to make the Op¦posite Party more willing to hearken to Terms.

Whatever shew of War they make, many other Con¦federates incline to obtain a Peace; France uses all i Interest to obtain a Peace, and will bid fair to fix a Peace if not with all the Allies, yet with some of them, who are so Considerable, as that the Less must come in last; but this is not yet, for some of the Confederat oppose it with great Steddiness.

The War in Pomerania goes on heavily, the Dane: blasted by Heaven, succeed in nothing they Attempt a∣gainst the Swedes, the Extremity of the Weather, Want, Sickness and Service, waste their Army, and the rest run away so fast, as will make the Whole unfit for their Designs. The Swedes defend themselves, and stand their Ground, and that Undertaking will prove un∣successful, as most unjust Wars do.

The Affair of the King of Sweden at Bender will prove yet Intricate; he will make Three Attempts to shake the Resolutions of the Grand Signior, and he almost per∣swades him to Break again with the Muscovites; but the Humour Changes at Constantinople, and he cannot compleat it yet, he continues there still.
A great Storm this Month may do great damage at Sea, and in the Ports of Europe; but it seems the Dutch will be the principal Sufferers.
A great Person in this Nation, and two in France, will yield to Fate about this Month.
In Britain great Contention about places, preferments, &c. And several People who have long expected to lose their places, shall fall, to make Room for another Party to guide the Nation.
No Signs of Peace among our selves yet, whatever may happen Abroad.

DIV1.HEAD: Second Prophecy.
DIV1.P: PEace creates War as War produces Peace, and the same Meetings and Consultations of Ambassadors and Plenipotentiaries have been had, but not being able to ad∣ust Matters, the Preparations for War go on; great ums of Money, and new invented Ways for the raising are now the Subject of the Councils of Europe. The Rich raise Strifes and War, and the Poor pay for it: New axes are laid by Authority, and the Heads of the Pro∣ctors are now employed to find out proper Methods for upplies, that we may be ready for War as well as for eace.

Great Struggling of Parties in Britain, in Opposition
to a Treaty of Peace; yet the Necessity of Affairs seems to make it unavoidable: Those that consent to Treat, do not all consent to it with a design of Peace; however, the Resolution of the Treaty seems to prevail, and accor∣dingly Ambassadors from all Parts are Named, and be∣gin their first Conference in form, though abundance of Memorials and Remonstrances are daily presented from Abroad against it.
The French press to peace; the English appear willing; the Dutch backward; smaller Allies indifferent; the Em¦peror absolutely refuses it.
Twice about February things appear ready to close, the Frenth offer largely; some Allies assent, some crave more, others reject all.

Strange foreboding Signals of the Calamities of Eu¦rope happen about this time, unusual Tempests, monstrous Births, surprizing Earthquakes, and the like: The Mor¦tality of Cattle spreads it self into several parts of Eu¦rope; a rare runner of a Mortality of another Kind, which shall Carry off a great many of the First Rank in Europe particularly in France and Spain.

DIV1.HEAD: Third Prophecy.
DIV1.P: GReat News from Sea about this Time to the Advan¦tage of our Enemies the French in some part o America. The Princes of Europe are now acting two contrary Extreams; they Treat of a Peace as if the resolved to have no more War; and they prepare for W as if they had no Thought of Peace.

All the proceedings on the Treaties of Peace seem end in a separate Accommodation, and as if every Bran were to look to it self: They begin to Act with Confidence, and less Satisfaction in one another than fo merly: France makes its Court here, and blusters a talks big there, just as its Interest guides: Britain a Holland hold together still, though great Endeavours many Sides to separate and disunite them.

The French use all the Art and Subtilty, peculiar that Nation, in order to separate the Confederates, a break them off from one another; nor is it altogether wi out Success; some Nations are in more Need of Pe
than others: Some carry on the War at less than others; and some are likely to make better Peace than others.

The Emperor stands obstinately out against a Peace, and threatens to carry on the War alone; complains of being Abandoned by the Allies; and refuses to divide, or part with the least Share of the Spanish Monarchy.
The Princes of the North, as more out of danger of the French, are backward to a Peace.
Britain puthes for a Peace Abroad, but great Heats and Quarrels about it at Home, where neither the Thing it self, or the Conditions, relish with the people so well as Peace ought to do.

The Parliament of Britain are now sitting; uncom∣mon Difficulties attend the raising Supplies, and restless Spirits push at making popular Distractions: The Friends to new Revolutions in Britain, both as to Ministry and Succession, though on different Foundations, and with differing Views join in this, to oppose and embarrass the constituted Government.
Great Changes are Brewing in the North of Europe, and the Kings of Denmark, Poland and Muscovy prepare as if they resolved to devour the Swede, but the latter holds up still against them all.

DIV1.HEAD: Fourth Prophecy.
DIV1.P: PEACE surprizes the World now rather by the va∣rious Shapes it appears in, than the Means it is procured by: The Nations seem rather to drive one another to Peace, than approve of it; and those that call what they have done, a making Peace, rather comply than are pleased with it.
However, they Treat with more Earnestness about it now, as being brought to the Crisis of Time when they must cast the Dye for Peace or War.

Something shall happen in the middle of this Transaction that shall put all Europe on new Measures. A Great Crown falls from a powerful Head about this Time; and Europe avoids a third War about Property, with great Difficulty.
Strange unseasonable Tempests and unwholesome Va∣pours fill the Air; and the darkest Day that was ever∣seen, will happen about April, though by no Eclipse of the Sun at all.

The War in Pomerania threatens greatly about this Time, the Swedes begin to appear strong; and the Princes of the Empire, the States of Holland and others, begin to concern themselves to prevent the Consequences of the War: The Muscovites, puff'd up with Success, talk big, and threaten the Empire; and the Confederate Princes begin to see too late the Fruits of Assisting to make that Barbarous Nation great in the World.
The King of Sweden begins to make new Stirs in the East, and continuing still among the Turks, at last brings the Muscovites and the Turks to a Quarrel; but no ar in Hand yet.

France falls in with the Swedish Designs at Consti∣nople, but acting the Cunning part, however leaves if in∣different, whether to get the Turks to break with the Czar or with the Venetians, as what may either Way embark the Empire in the War.
The Venetians Arm, and some little Hostilities happen at Sea; but no War yet.

About this Time, the Season returning, the Plague be∣gins to give new Alarms in Europe, and spreads it self in∣to Mecklenberg, Holstein and Pomerania, being brought thither by the Danish Armies and Fleets: Rostock, and Strlsund begin to feel the terrible Effects of it: The City of Hamburgh escapes yet.
Three great Persons in the King of Denmark's Family else, and perhaps himself; his Allies not effectually assisting him, the Danish Affairs are reduced very low.

DIV1.HEAD: Fifth Prophecy.
DIV1.P:
NOW they begin the Campaigns; some Fight and some Treat, and some both Treat and Fight; and some who talk as big as any, neither Fight nor Treat: The War goes on Awkwardly and Heavily, as if they ought with an Iil Will: French Cunning prevails in many
Courts, and they have Peace in Effect, when they have War in Appearance: Thus the War now rather Impo∣verishes than Destroys, and there is likely to be more Money than Blood lost this Campaign.

Farther off, the War and the Plague punishes Europe together, the last having made desolate the most Flourish∣ing Countries, spreads now into the Empire, by slow steps coming this Way still, threatens us more and more. Hamburgh feels this terrible Enemy a little before the hot Weather comes in, but more afterwards: Pomerania is now miserably afflicted with War, Pestilence and Fa∣mine; no Pen can describe the Distresses of the Inhabi∣tants of that Country.

The New Emperor begins to threaten Europe with a Mighty Army, and talks Great Things: France gets Ground by crafty and subtil Councils, rather than the Sword; yet an Action happens in Catalonia, to the Disadvantage of the Imperialists; Charles VI. pushes great forces into Italy, and prepares for new Wars on the Side of Provence, but he wants Shipping to Transport his Forces into Spain, and unless the Con∣federates supply, he must give it over in Catalonia.
Death gives a great Blow in England, which will have an Effect upon the publick Measures; but the QUEEN is Safe, and the Hopes of her Enemies are not so high as before.

The Parties in England carry on a furious War, and fight many Battles, which, tho' without Blood, have very fatal Effects upon the Nation: Things look dark, and the People begin to see the Circumstances their own Folly has brought them to: National Divisions threaten the Nations Peace, Trade lost, Credit sunk, and the People uneasy.
The Queen exhorts to Peace: What People but those would let her perswade in vain?
Great Strife at Court, heaving and thrusting in and out; and every Head has his Party to push on his Inte∣rest among the People, and make him appear formidable and popular

Some promising Hopes of a General Peace begin to ap∣pear, but it goes off again; the Emperor stands out yet,
and obtains some Allies more than was expected; France offers to restore to Britain, and make our Queen Arbitress of Europe; France resolves to have a Peace with Britain and Holland, by Granting rather more than they Ask.

DIV1.HEAD: Sixth Prophecy.
DIV1.P: STill they Fight on, and Treat on; nor does any Suc∣cess on this Side or that influence the Plenipotenti∣aries on either Side: The French decline coming to any de∣cisive Action, but stand on the defensive in all Places, ex∣cept Spain, that no Blow in the Field may oblige them to yield to meaner Terms than they were willing to stoop to before.

The uncommon Symptoms of Europe's Distress, now shew that they were not vain Signals; the Earthquake in Saxony and France; the Disease of the Oxen in Pa∣dua and other parts of Italy; the strange Distemper: that raged both among Men and Horses: What were they but Fore-runners of the Plague which this Year, and about this time of the Year invades many Countries in Europe with a dreadful Violence.

Last Year I foretold you it should come into Turkey and Hungaria, and both of them have prov'd true: Con∣stantinople shall Bury an Hundred Thousand e'er this Year shall enter far in; Belgrade and Buda have found it true also from both these: Expect it now in the Do∣minion of the Venetian and the Emperor, and on both sides the Adriatick Gulph.

If Hamburgh escapes not the Month of May, Britain escapes not this Year, and if both escape this Year, let them take it for a Reprieve from Heaven till the next, to move them to Repentance before the Sword is drawn, and before the Destroyer lands among them.
Now the Intriegues of the Swedes and Tartar at Ben∣der break out; and the Turks again animated against the Muscovices, threaten a new War, but no Action on ei∣ther Side yet.

The Councils of Europe are now universally perplex'd
and great Revolutions will happen in divers parts of the World, nor will the least of them happen among us and our Allies.

The War in the North begins to grow formidable to the rest of Europe, and the Policies of the Muscovites and King of Poland threaten the Empire. A Great Prince, hitherto an Enemy to France and French Councils, ap∣pears now acted and influenc'd by the Council of Ver∣sailles, at least as far as may serve to threaten Europe, and force the Confederates to turn their Eyes to the Baltick, and divert them from other Efforts.
At last the Dane is Ruin'd by the War with Sweden, and obliged by the English and Dutch to give over his Designs, and sit still, and glad to do it too, without the Swedes falling upon them.

Death threatens a Great Person in the Hanover Court; but Britain having no less than four immediate succeed∣ing Heirs there to her Crown, need not fear having an Occasion to make a new Settlement of the Entail.

DIV1.HEAD: Seventh Prophecy.
DIV1.P: NOW we are flatter'd with Hopes of bringing the Peace to a Conclusion, but Obstructions still ap∣pear; the Emperor pushes and presses the French on a War; the Armies on every Side are in the Field, and Prince Eugene tells us, He will make good what was boasted on Behalf of the Emperor: He passes the Rhine, enters Alsatia, offers Battle to the French, who won't Fight, hoping to Master the Germans a better Way.
Madam Maintenon looks into her Grave, as if to see how she likes it; but if she escapes June, she sur∣vives still, and recovers.
The Dutchess of Burgundy seems to be pointed at by Death, and a great French General also.
Lewis XIV. lives still, and carries his Point at last to gain a Peace, with keeping his Grandson upon the Throne of Spain, but Capitulates to quit several Branches of the Monarchy to Secure the rest.
The French succeed again about this time at an At∣tempt at Sea, and bid fair to Establish themselves in A∣merica.

War breaks out now between the Turks and the Ve∣netians, and France Insults the Venetians at the same time; yet the Turks make no immediate Expedition in∣to the Venetian Territories, being cautious of a War with the Emperor: French Councils embroil the Turkish Court, and the Grand Vzier complies with the Propoals for War, or falls, or gives Way to those who are of another Mind.
A Battle in Pomerania about the Month of June, and fought with great Obstinacy and Blood on both Sides; the Swedes have the real Advantage, though the other claim victory according to Custom.
Very hot, yet unseasonable and sickly Weather in these Parts of the World; and great Ravages by the Plague in the North and East Parts of Europe.
Divided Councils perplex Europe more than the War; this Years War being rather Chargeable than Bloody.

DIV1.HEAD: Eighth Prophecy.
DIV1.P: FRANCE having gain'd Ground by proposing Peace, begins now to exert himself to use Force where the Ambassador of his Treaty has weakned or divided the Allies.

His Intrigues now affect several Parts of Italy, as Venice, Genoa, Florence, and the Pope. The latter pre∣pares to leave the World, and two Cardinals either go before to lead him the Way, or go just along with him.

The War in the North grows hotter than ever: The Swedes push their Enemies in several Parts, and only want Money to make them compleatly Victorious; the Overtures for Mediation between them are still oppos'd by Sweden, who ventures the Ruin of all, rather than stoop to his Mortal Enemy the King of Poland.
Earthquakes and Irruptions of Fire do a great deal of Michief in Italy, and help on Europe's Calamities.

The Emperor renews the War in Catalonia, in Op∣position to all Propositions of Peace, and will not be brought to consent to quit the Dominion of Spain: A Battle about the Month of July, in Spain. and Count Staramberg Wounded, but Victor.
The Plague threatens to cross the Elbe about July, and to decide the Controversies of Europe.

About this Time let London, Fdinburgh and Yarm. enquire narrowly into some Ships, who in spight of a∣rantines, will set on Shore some Diseased People, and several die of strange and violent Fevers; yet the great Terror begins not yet.

DIV1.HEAD: Ninth Prophecy.
DIV1.P: WAR and Pestilence are now in their Heighth, and Reap the sad Bloody Harvest of Europe: I will hope Great-Britain, Holland and France shall Escape this Year, but dare not expect any longer Sparing; yet Men Repent not, and Princes of the World push on their Ambitious Designs as if Heaven was entirely at Peaece with them, and no Judgements gone out against them.

'Tis time now for Europe to undo what, for ten Years past, they have been doing, viz. aggrandizing the Wild and Barbarous Nation of the Muscovites, who by a small Advantage in Pomeren, growing forward, talk in∣solently to the Princes and Powers of Europe, and be∣gin to intermeddle with the Affairs of the Emperor; but he receives some Threats from the Dutch, which he resents very much.

The King of France declines apace both in Health and Fortune, and is either in, or very near his Reposi∣tory. About September the Dissentions among the Po∣pish Clergy rise to a great Heighth in France and Italy, and threaten the Popish Hierarchy of Europe with such Divisions as shall end in the preparing of People for the
Light of True Religion, and practising the Gospel of Christ among them.
These Divisions slacken the Heat of the Popish Clergy against the Protestants in France; and in Languedoc they appear more open than usual.

A great Faction in the French Court about the lat∣ter end of the Year, and a great Man carries it so high, that his Grandfather appears uneasie at him, and something Jealous. A great General quite out of Fa∣vour; Monsieur Villars Opposes the Duke of Berry, and threatens him with the King's Displeasure, which he re∣sents to a Degree implacable.

DIV1.HEAD: Tenth Prophecy.
DIV1.P: Aseeming Conclusion of the Peace has been now the Effect of a large Treaty: France oppress'd by the War, makes larger Concessions, and the Influence of some Princes assist: The Emperor, tho' not able to effect all his Designs, seems more flexible to Conditions, being willing to get Spain and the Indies from the French, yet the many Interests which the several Parties pursue in this War, are not so easie to be adjusted as that a full Conclusion can be made.

In Flanders the utmost Artifice is made use of on both Sides, as well to push on, as to fend off the War. The French lose Ground, and the Confederates make odd Attacks; and this shewing only a long retracting of the War, which many are weary of, and make a Handle to press to Peace.

We find the Conclusions at Ʋtrecht unable to put a final End to Jealousies and War; and tho' we have now the Appearance of Peace, they all stand with Sword it Hand, as if ready to break out into a New War.

The Turks and Muscovites go to War in Earnest; and about this Month some Action happens between them to the Disadvantage of the Muscovites: The King of Sweden is now in the Field, and his Affairs in Pomeren take a new Turn.

DIV1.HEAD: Eleventh Prophecy.
DIV1.P: SOme People think the Peace of Europe is settled now, and some think it as far off as ever; yet new Mea∣sures at Court make new Divisions among the Parties: Great Discontent about Management endangers the New Ministry, and if a thorow Change does not happen in the British Court, it will be nearer to it than ever it was before, and the Escape very Narrow.
Scotland feels great Disorders about this Time, and Things look very dark on that Side. Some popular Riots happen, as is usual, in Distemper'd Countries be∣fore more publick Commotions happen.

Britain, like a Body neither Sick or Well, enjoys neither Peace, or makes War; and the Disatisfactions at Home swell up so, that honest Men know not which to desire: The French rejoice at a Peace, some here call it so, but others say it is Criminal to call it a Peace, and that a War is nearer a Peace than the Condition we are in at present.

The Dutch, and some other Confederates, not think∣ing themselves kindly used in, or secure by the late Treaty, Arm, and refuse to Declare themselves upon what Occasion several Endeavours are used to foment a Breach between the British and Dutch, but do not bring Things to that heighth yet.
Winter and cold Weather makes Health encrease a little, and the Pestilence stops; but the War goes on in the North with great Fury, and the Swedes prevail in several Places.

DIV1.HEAD: Twelfth Prophecy.
DIV1.P: THE Year ends on our Side with Plans, Schemes, Plots and Designs of Parties for the next: French Interests and French Parties influence too much our Af∣fairs; and the Knowledge of it makes every Man, and every party of Men Jealous of each other.

France has made but too much Advantage of the Divisions of the Year among the Confederates, and has obtain'd some advantageous Conditions, which if they had been better United, he could never have arrived to; yet the English. Court has given Checks to some of his Encroachments, and talks roughly to him about some others, on which he abates some Pretensions.
What is wanting to fix and settle a General Peace, and what Conditions were Agreed to, they now begin to put in Execution, and to settle the General Quiet.

Councils, States, Parliaments, &c. Assemble now, and People flatter themselves that War and Mise∣ry, Poverty and Taxes shall cease, and Trade Flou∣rish; but we see it yet but in Faith and Futurity: GOD send us better News for next Year.
